He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
not wild, but deep, where silence drowns,

I do not flinch, nor turn away,

he sees the dusk in my delay,
the truth I hide from even muse.

Perhaps we're both a touch unmoored,
adrift in tides no map defines;
our sanity a thin veneer,
but in his eyes, I see the signs
of someone who has loved too long,
and known the dark where songs go wrong.

So let him stare with storm-filled gaze,
I’ll meet him where the shadows rise;
for in his madness, love stays,
beneath the moon’s unblinking eyes.

So I release the spool, let go,

For memory warms, but life must burn—

instance_metrics.response: People are happy when the sun spills gold across cracked sidewalks, when laughter leaks from open windows like steam from old radiators. They are happy in the quiet rebellion of dandelions breaking through concrete, in the way strangers exchange glances on a crowded train and feel less alone. Happiness hums in the grocery clerk’s tired smile, in the dog that runs in circles chasing its tail for no reason at all. It lives in the crumpled love note found in a winter coat pocket, in the smell of burnt toast that reminds you someone is near. People are happy not because life is perfect, but because it is pulsing—wild, flawed, and full of small fires that refuse to die. They are happy when they dance barefoot in the kitchen at midnight, when they cry during romantic comedies they pretend not to watch. They are happy in the messy middle, where joy isn’t earned but discovered—like a forgotten melody suddenly remembered. People are happy when they forget to be searching, when they let the world brush against their skin like a whispered secret. And in that moment, even sorrow wears a softer face.

They are happy in the clutter of lives lived fully—the mismatched socks, the books stacked like unstable towers, the way voices rise in off-key harmony during long car rides. It thrives in shared silence, in hands that hold not to possess but to say, 'I’m here.' People are happy when they forget time, when minutes dissolve into stories told over lukewarm tea. They are happy in the cracks—where light gets in, where roots take hold, where life insists on growing, green and defiant. instance_metrics.response: One dark, dark night—it was long ago, / When time unspooled like thread from snow. / The sky wore cloaks of bruise and tar, / And stars blinked out—each one a scar. / A child stood barefoot in the glen, / Holding a clock with hands that ran… backwards. / The trees hummed hymns in minor keys, / Summoning memories never meant to be. / A rabbit spoke in human tongue: / 'You left the door unlatched, young one.' / I followed it through thorn and mist, / To where the world was never kissed. / A house of glass, with breath-stained walls, / Contained a thousand ghostly calls. / My mother’s voice, my sister’s cry— / All moments lost beneath the sky. / I reached to touch, but saw instead / My own face aging in the glass. / The night collapsed into a sigh, / And morning lied when it said goodbye. / One dark, dark night—it still resides, / In every dream where truth abides.

instance_metrics.response: One dark, dark night—it was long ago, / Before the clocks forgot to go, / When shadows stretched like living vines, / And oceans kept celestial rhymes. / The world exhaled in velvet hush, / As comet-dreams went out in a rush. / Beneath a bridge of fractured stone, / A fiddle played—its song unknown. / A tramp with eyes of liquid gold / Spun tales of cities overbold, / Of empires built on lies and lace, / That vanished without a trace. / He sang of queens with raven hair, / Who danced on air, dissolved in air. / I dropped a coin—no copper, but a tear— / And vanished into atmosphere. / Now I drift between world and wisp, / A memory someone else might miss. / No name, no form, just echo and tone, / From one dark, dark night—long, long ago, not gone.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'One dark, dark night--it was long ago,'

instance_metrics.response:
One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
When moonlight fled and stars burned low,
I wandered through a whispering wood,
Where time stood still and silence stood.

The trees like sentinels of old
Held secrets never meant to be told,
And shadows danced with hollow eyes,
Beneath a sky of ashen skies.

I heard a voice—so soft, so thin—
Like breath escaping buried kin,
It called my name in vowels stretched,
A melody of dreams unkept.

Then footsteps, slow on frost-strewn ground,
No shape, no form—but there, it's found.
It passed like scent on winter air,
Leaving only echoes in my hair.

I reached for what I couldn’t see,
A memory not mine, yet part of me.
And though the years have dulled the fright,
That dark, dark night still owns the night.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'One dark, dark night--it was long ago,'

instance_metrics.response:
One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
I slipped beneath the skin of snow.
The earth exhaled a lullaby,
As constellations blinked goodbye.

A fox with eyes of molten gold
Trod paths where frozen stories told
Of lovers lost and kingdoms drowned,
Beneath the roots where ghosts were found.

I followed trails of silver thread,
Spun by a moon long thought dead,
Through valleys where the winds compose
Symphonies in minor prose.

We danced with shadows, three or four,
Who once were real, but now are more—
Beings born from breath and dread,
Wearing masks of what we’d said.

No dawn arrived, or so I thought,
Until I woke, and truly sought:
Not light, but truth in darkness' glow—
That night still walks… and I still know.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'One dark, dark night--it was long ago,'

instance_metrics.response:
One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
I fell into a well of slow.
Not water, but time pooled deep,
Where memories both wake and sleep.

I saw my hands, yet not my own,
Carving names on marble stone.
A child laughed—a sound so clear—
But vanished with the dying year.

The air was thick with unsung songs,
And dust that tasted like goodbyes.
Clocks melted on a rusted wall,
Each tick a nail, each chime a fall.

I met a figure wrapped in thread,
Who whispered all the things I’d said
To those I loved, but let slip by—
Now echoes beneath a weeping sky.

I climbed back up with hollow chest,
Carrying silence as my guest.
That night still hums beneath my breath—
A lullaby of near-death.

instance_metrics.response:
One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
When moonlight drowned in storm-wracked skies,
A lantern flickered, low and slow,
Beneath the weeping willows' sighs.

I walked a path of sunken stone,
Where shadows danced with whispered lies,
And every step was chilled to bone,
As time dissolved and silence rose.

A figure stood in tattered gray,
No face, no eyes—just hollow breath,
It pointed west and slipped away,
Leaving only echoes underneath.

The woods grew thick with ancient names,
Carved deep in bark and half-erased,
Each syllable a tongue of flames,
Each memory a curse rehearsed.

I never reached the distant shore
Where candles bloomed on ghostly trees,
But still I hear that whispering door,
And feel the wind pull down to me.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
Yet every night feels just the same,
The past won’t rest, the winds still blow,
And someone calls my name.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'One dark, dark night--it was long ago,'

instance_metrics.response:
One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
I slipped between the seams of time,
Where clocks unwound and rivers froze,
And stars forgot their ancient rhyme.

The sky cracked open, deep and wide,
And spilled a song of lost regrets,
Each note a soul that tried to hide,
A chorus drenched in violet.

I met a fox with silver eyes,
Who spoke in riddles spun from frost:
"The truth you seek will be your guise,
And every answer is a cost."

We danced on ice that wasn’t there,
On rooftops floating in the mist,
While children’s laughter filled the air,
From dreams that could no longer exist.

I woke upon a mossy stone,
With feathers tangled in my hair,
And never since have I been known
To speak of what I saw out there.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
But sometimes, when the world is still,
The fox returns, and soft and low,
It sings that song against my will.

instance_metrics.response:
One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
I found a door in mid-air, thin as breath,
Carved with runes that pulsed with glow,
And humming just beneath my step.

It opened not to room or hall,
But to a garden made of sound—
Where roses bloomed from violin calls,
And daisies spun from lost love songs unbound.

A woman wove with threads of light,
Her fingers stitching grief and grace,
She said, "You’ve wandered into night,
But here, all endings find their place."

She showed me laughter turned to rain,
And promises that learned to fly,
Each broken vow reborn again
As fireflies across the sky.

I stayed until the clock unwound,
Then slipped back through the vanishing frame,
Now every time the stars are drowned,
I swear I hear that garden’s name.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
But petals sometimes drift into my room,
And when they land, I softly know:
The world is stranger than the gloom.

instance_metrics.response:
One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
When stars like salt were flung too far to glow.
A lantern swung from hands I do not know,
And shadows danced on cliffs where silence grew.

The sea, a breath held deep beneath the hill,
Whispered of names the wind refused to tell.
I stood barefoot on stones that echoed still,
And heard a lullaby from some old well.

It sang of wolves who wore a human grin,
Of clocks unstrung, of time undone by sin.
A raven perched upon a crooked spire,
And dropped a key into the hungry mire.

No footprints marked the path I seemed to take,
Yet footprints followed—light as mist, they’d break.
I woke inside a house of hollow walls,
Where mirrors showed no face at all, no face at all.

Now every dusk I strain to hear that tune,
That half-remembered, moonless lullaby.
One dark, dark night—it wasn’t me, not me,
But something wore my bones and walked the sky.

One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
A child tucked deep where attic rafters bow.
No moon, no hush, just ticking floorboards slow,
And something humming through the keyhole’s glow.

It wasn’t words, that tune—more like the sound
Of roots uncurling under ancient ground,
Or glass remembering a shattered pane,
Or love that stayed, though love had left in pain.

The walls exhaled a scent of cinnamon,
And photographs began to walk and run—
Grandfather waltzed with ghosts in velvet gowns,
While teacups floated, spilling silent downs.

A clock unwound its hands with weary sigh,
And poured the hour into a raven’s eye.
Time pooled like ink upon the wooden floor,
And drew a door where none had been before.

Beyond it stood a forest made of breath,
Where trees spoke names that cheated even death.
I stepped inside—but only for a beat—
Then woke with moss grown in my heartbeat.

Now when the night grows thick and thick with shade,
I hear that hum, and know I’m not unpaid:
The past is not a wound that fades away,
But someone knocking, dressed in yesterday.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'One dark, dark night--it was long ago,'

instance_metrics.response:
One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
A train rushed through a valley clad in snow.
No lights aboard, no whistle, just the groan
Of iron dreaming on a track of bone.

I stood beside the rails, though I’d no cause,
Wearing a coat stitched full of broken laws.
My pockets hummed with letters never sent,
Each stamped with fire, each sealed with lament.

The windows flickered—faces, pale and thin—
Eyes like hollows where the stars had been.
One child pressed a palm against the glass,
And mouthed a word that time refused to pass.

I reached to touch the echo of her hand,
When thunder cracked the sky like broken land.
A flock of clocks took flight from out the roof,
Their hands all pointing to a single truth:

That every choice we bury in the past
Still breathes beneath the snow, still holds us fast.
That night, I learned the dark is not a place,
But memory wearing sorrow’s face.

Now when the winter wind begins to moan,
I hear that train—still traveling, alone.
One dark, dark night—it was long ago,
And yet it rides through every dream I know.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'One dark, dark night--it was long ago,'

instance_metrics.response:
Fire: a tongue that speaks in shadows,
licking the edges of the night.
It whispers ancient hymns to embers,
dancing in the hollows of forgotten rites.

Not merely flame, but memory unspooling—
the hearth where elders told their tales,
the pyre where love and loss were burning,
the forge where destinies grew pale.

It sings of caves and stolen sparks,
of Prometheus cloaked in starless air,
of campfires under meteor showers,
and candles trembling in despair.

Fire does not apologize for light.
It devours wood, yet gives us sight.
It warms the hands but scars the soul,
a paradox in coal and coal.

And when the logs collapse to ash,
and silence settles in the pan,
it leaves behind a fragrant hush,
and dreams that smolder, not yet gone.

So I stand before its flickering face,
a child again, wide-eyed, undone—
for in its gaze I see my place:
brief spark, then kindling for the sun.

instance_metrics.response:
Fire: a red fox darting through the dry grass,
alert, electric, a thief in the breath of August.
It doesn’t ask. It takes. It passes.
A rumor turned riot, a spark turned lust.

It paints the sky in urgent strokes,
orange confession, blackened hymns.
The wind fans it like a joke
no one invited, but everyone sings.

It curls around the oak like a lover,
then swallows it whole in a crackling embrace.
No mercy. No closure. Just flavor and cover
of smoke that veils the moon’s pale face.

In cities, it sleeps in gaslit eyes,
blue and tamed on kitchen stoves.
But let the wires fray, let the vapor rise—
it remembers how to hunt, how to rove.

We worship it. We fence it in.
We roast marshmallows above its grin.
But deep down, we know the truth we dread:
it’s not our servant. We’re the fuel instead.

Fire: a child’s finger near the candle’s crown,
a gasp, a flinch, the wick untouched.
Yet something burns—the world comes down
in golden pulses, lightly coupled.

It’s not the heat but what it wakes:
the scent of birthday cakes long gone,
the lanterns floating down dark lakes,
the riots painted on the lawn.

Fire is time in motion—brief,
consuming yesterdays to feed the now.
A leaf, a letter, a burst of grief—
flame turns them all to floating vow.

It doesn’t judge. It does not choose.
It dances where the oxygen leads.
A forest, a home, a lover’s ruse—
all equal in its need and speed.

And when it sleeps, in gray and dust,
it leaves behind a hollow hum,
a silence warm with aftertrust,
and shadows where the bright once come.

So I write this poem in its name,
not to praise or to condemn,
but to whisper, flame to flame:
'I remember. I am.'

Ash falls like snow on silent ground,

Fire, you teach us to burn with purpose:

awakening myths buried beneath sod.
It crawls through veins of ancient coal,
dreams of dinosaurs turned to soul.
It flickers in streetlamps, in lovers’ eyes,
in riots where justice finally cries.
It braids the air above desert sands,
a mirage that burns with invisible hands.
Fire lives in the chef’s searing pan,
the poet’s rage, the rebel’s plan.
It leaps from drumbeat to dancer’s feet,
a rhythm too hot for time to delete.
Once, it taught humans to cook their fear,
to forge a blade, to draw near,
to gather close in primal ring,
where shadow-puppets began to sing.
Now it rages in server farms,
a digital blaze beneath electric arms.
It melts glaciers with quiet spite,
transforms polar bears into ghost-light.
Yet, in stillness, when flames retreat,
we smell the truth beneath the heat:
that fire is memory’s sharpest sense,
the cost of warmth, the price of sense.
It does not forgive, it does not hide—
it simply burns, with nowhere to bide.
Fire: the first word, the final sound,
the silence after the world burns down.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire:'

instance_metrics.response:
Fire: a child’s scribble in the dark,
a crayon of chaos, bright and stark.
It toasts marshmallows into black lace,
leaves sweetness charred on a stick’s cold face.
It powers rockets that punch the moon,
and kerosene lamps in a monsoon room.
It flickers in lanterns on ghost ships lost,
lighting the way for souls long crossed.
Fire is the blush on a blacksmith’s cheek,
the molten ring he’s sworn to keep.
It dances in volcanoes with ballet grace,
then erupts in fury, time and space
bent by its tantrum, earth split wide,
new mountains born from molten pride.
But in the kitchen, it’s gentle and tame,
boiling tea, calling each name
for supper. It crackles in board games played,
while snow piles high and the world’s delayed.
Fire is the first kiss too fast to last,
consuming passion built to burn out fast.
It’s the glow in protest signs at night,
the torch of truth in oppressive light.
It’s the fever dream of a dying star,
and the cigarette glow in a parked car.
Fire: neither sinner nor saint, but force—
the universe’s primal source
of warmth, of change, of sudden end,
the oldest friend we can’t defend.
It asks no permission. It owes no debt.
Fire simply is. And isn’t that what’s left?

Now I carry its spark in the cage of my chest,
A flicker that neither submits nor is blessed.
It does not warm me—it *knows* me instead,

Fire: not weapon, nor comfort, nor pyre,

I once tried to cage it in lanterns of glass,

I fed it my letters, my maps, and my past—
It crunched them like leaves and gave nothing back.

Yet still, I return with a twig and a spark,
Hoping to bargain, to tame, to embark.
But fire doesn’t bargain. It blooms in the dark,
A joke that the universe whispers: *You are a lark.*

So I dance on the edge of its radiant stage,
A moth with a dream, and a very short age.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun, why dart'st thou through my windowpanes?
Must thou disturb the lovers' union, break our sweet, secluded reigns?
We need no calendar—her eyes my day, her breath the dawn's first bloom;
Thy age demands rest, yet thou dost chase the world with golden broom.

Thou think'st thy beams so potent, wise, that kings and peasants bow to thee,
But love, once lit, knows no eclipse, no season, hour, or decree.
Go, tell schoolboys tardy for class, rouse sour farmers from their loam,
But know this: our bed is a cosmos where time has lost its home.

Shine on the fields where ripening stands, gild the crops and guide the plow,
But do not dare to touch this room—our silence makes its own now.
One drop of her smile could blind thee, one sigh could quench thy fire;
Go, melt the winter's frozen side, but leave our twin hearts entire.

Thou art half as happy as we, bound to orbit, cold and far—
We, though still, contain the universe: two souls, one boundless star.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun, tearing night’s lace,

You, ancient traveler, bound by sky’s tight tether,

For every glance we trade outshines your gold,
Every kiss a supernova, fiercely bold.
So hush, old fireball, fade into the blue—
Our love makes its own dawn; we make our truth.

We meet many people in life, like stars adrift in night,
Some flicker soft, a passing glow, a momentary light.
Others blaze with steady fire, carving trails through doubt,
Leaving constellations etched when paths run out.
A handshake, a laugh, a glance across a crowded room,
Each soul a novel sealed, yet read in fragrant bloom.
Some stay like roots beneath the soil, unseen but holding fast,
While others drift like autumn leaves, too fleeting to outlast.
We trade our stories, stitch by stitch, on time’s unyielding loom,
Weaving silken threads of joy, and shadows of looming gloom.
A teacher’s voice still hums behind my thoughts,
A stranger’s kindness in the rain, one lesson life has taught.
No meeting is without its weight, though some may seem so slight—
Even silence speaks in echoes when the moon swallows the light.
And though we part, we carry them—shards within the core,
The quiet hum of every soul we've brushed against before.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We meet many people in life,'

instance_metrics.response:
We meet many people in life—some wear masks of glass,
Transparent, yet unbreakable, built to let time pass.
A barista who knows my order, the bus driver with a grin,
Each a verse in life’s long song, a fleeting, fragile hymn.
Some arrive like thunderstorms, reshaping all the land,
With words that crack the bedrock where I build my stand.
Lovers who paint the sky in hues I never knew were real,
Then vanish like the morning mist, leaving wounds that never heal.
We are islands shifting on tides we can’t control,
Each encounter a bridge of rope, a temporary stroll.
A child’s laughter on the street, a war veteran’s gaze,
All part of the endless current through the soul’s deep maze.
We borrow pieces of each other, then return them as we go,
In every face, a universe—brief, bright, and bittersweet, you know.
And when at last I fade into the quiet, star-lit air,
I’ll be someone else’s memory, someone else’s poem somewhere.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We meet many people in life,'

instance_metrics.response:
We meet many people in life—like books on endless shelves,
Some skimmed in haste, some read in depth, some carried out of themselves.
A nameless face on subway stairs, a whisper in the rain,
Each a world with hidden rooms, a joy, a wound, a pain.
Some hand us keys we didn’t know we'd need to open doors,
While others leave their fingerprints on hearts they barely saw.
Friendships bloom like sudden flowers after summer's drought,
While enemies, like winter frost, reveal what truth is about.
We are mosaics made of glances, laughter, tears, and lies,
Every soul a brushstroke painting vast internal skies.
A mentor’s nod, a lover’s fight, a stranger’s shared umbrella—
All ripple through the silent stream of who we are and whether
We rise or fall. And still we walk through crowds, both near and far,
Carrying ghosts and greetings in the lanterns of a star.
For every meeting plants a seed, though none may see it grow—
We are gardens shaped by every soul we’ve brushed below.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We meet many people in life,'

instance_metrics.response:
We meet many people in life, fleeting as leaves on the wind,
Some brush past with laughter, others leave scars within.
A handshake, a glance, a name half-remembered—
Souls crossing paths beneath the same trembling sky.
There was the girl who taught me constellations,
And the old man who wept at a train station,
While the stranger who shared his bread on a bridge
Never knew he saved a drowning spirit.
Each face a story half-told, a mirror reflecting
Some hidden fragment I thought I’d buried.
We meet, we speak, we drift like migrating birds,
Carrying pieces of each other through time.
Even silence speaks in the wake of goodbyes.
And though most vanish like footprints in rain,
Their echoes shape the way I breathe,
The way I love, the way I remain—
Not untouched, but transformed.
For every soul I’ve met has sown a seed,
And life is the garden they helped me grow.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We meet many people in life,'

instance_metrics.response:
We meet many people in life, like letters lost in the mail,
Some arrive crumpled, some never unfold,
Yet each carries a message written in dust or gold.
There’s the boy who laughed with thunder in his voice,
And the woman who danced barefoot in a storm, no choice.
A million glances, a thousand quiet words,
A network of ghosts that hum beneath my skin.
They come like seasons—some burn, some freeze,
Others bloom too fast, too fragile to keep.
I met a poet who spoke in colors,
And a silence that taught me how to listen.
Even the ones I barely knew—
The barista who warmed my cup each morning,
The child who drew suns on a city wall—
Still live in the rhythm of my days.
People are not just moments, but tides,
Wearing down the cliffs of who I was.
And when I close my eyes, I hear them all:
A chorus of footsteps, fading and near,
Whispering: *You are not who you were,
Because we were here.*
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We meet many people in life,'

instance_metrics.response:
We meet many people in life, like stars blinking in a stranger’s sky—
Brief, brilliant, then gone behind cloud or time.
Some ignite something dormant, a fuse in the chest;
Others just pass, like shadows on pavement at noon.
I remember the friend who vanished mid-sentence,
And the lover who stayed just long enough to change my gravity.
There was the neighbor who sang off-key every Tuesday,
And the hitchhiker who spoke only in riddles,
But gave me a compass with no needle.
Every handshake a doorway, every goodbye a wall.
Yet walls have cracks, and through them, light—
Echoes of voices that still call my name
When the world goes quiet.
We are mosaics of everyone we’ve brushed against,
Fragments fused by chance, by choice, by accident.
We meet, we part, we linger in memory,
Like footprints on someone else’s moon.
And though most names will fade like ink in rain,
The imprint remains—
A warmth in the pulse, a shift in the air,
Proof that to meet is to alter,
And to alter is to live.

instance_metrics.response:
We meet many people in life, like leaves on different winds,
Tossed through seasons, shifting shapes, where no true path begins.
Some brush so close they steal your breath, a scent you can’t replace,
Others vanish in the fog, leaving only empty space.

There’s the child who shared her crayons in the sandbox of June,
The man who cursed you on the bridge beneath a harvest moon.
The nurse whose hands were steady when the world began to spin,
And the ghost of someone almost—almost let you in.

Each touch, a ripple through the skin of time’s deep, silent lake,
A word, a smile, a silence—all of them mistakes
Or miracles. We gather them like shells along the shore,
Not knowing which will sing of peace, which ache forevermore.

We meet in hospitals and bars, in queues and quiet glens,
In texts half-sent, in letters burned, in lost and found again.
Some teach us how to fall, some how to rise,
Some vanish with the morning, taking pieces of our eyes.

And though we cross a thousand hearts, forget most names and faces,
Traces linger in the blood, in dreams, in quiet places.
We meet many people in life—brief flames, or long-burning fires,
